posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18817375
>>18817354
Dressing balances and seasons the vegetables. A big bowl of salad for 4 people only needs at most half a cup of good dressing.

Here is my favorite recipe:
4tbs evoo
1tbs dijon mustard
1tbs of good white wine vinegar
.5-1 clove of minced garlic
S&P

Mix everything except oil. Slowly drizzle evoo into mix until emulsified. Add 2 tsp of water to thin.

Healthy, simple, light dressing that seasons everything and brightens up the greens while not over powering any of the other flavors.

I worked in a kitchen for a few years and every time I used one of those things with anything that had eggs in it, it would scramble the eggs because the thing runs so fast, and the sharp blades cut through the eggs so everything gets hot. It is almost always better in my experience to just use a whisk and do it manually. However the immersion blender did work very well for a few things I remember - pizza sauce, honey mustard, ranch, blue cheese, I think because these things have solid pieces it helps to cut them up and make everything smooth

For future reference, if you're looking for a dish that serves the same purpose: Feijoada à Transmontana - red (or black) bean stew with tons of pork, cabbage, carrots, spicy sausage, garlic, onion, cumin, black pepper, paprika and a bit of tomato paste. A secret ingredient is a tiny bit of pork blood, but that's my secret ingredient, not a standard one.From the north of Portugal. Make some white rice to accompany it and it can last you all week. Buy the cheap cuts of pork with gelatin and bone and salt them a day in advance.
I found this recipe in english: https://www.196flavors.com/portugal-feijoada-transmontana/
Adapt it to your needs.

>>18807925
Coffee:20g
Water:230g @ 79°C
Brewer:Inverted
Filter:Paper

Grind coffee at "7.3" on a Malkoenig EK43
Heat water to 79°C
Add 60g of water
Turbulent wiggle for 15 seconds
Allow 30 seconds of bloom
Add the rest of the water in 10 seconds
Press down for 45 seconds

Total brew time - 1:35

posts.com:
I had 6g of beans left at the end of a bag, not enough to make a pour over, so I ground them, threw them in my Hario Switch, and made them with my usual recipe, just scaled down to 100g of water. It came out really good! It actually brought out more of the tasting notes than when I used the V60, which was stronger on the fruity notes but less on the Earl Grey notes that are supposed to be present. That's one thing I like about the Switch, you can use the same recipe for a wide range of doses and coffee types and still get good results. That probably applies to other immersion brewing methods as well. Another time I did this with only 3g of a different bag of coffee, and that came out good too.

What do you do when you get to the end of a bag?

for $26 a bag yes i would say it is better than store trash.
well as long as you are provided with as much information as possible
farmer
location
varietal
region
height it was grown at
how it was processed
when it was roasted
how it was roasted
these are the basics, if a seller cant provide these then they aren't worth buying from.
also anything past medium dark at the very most is not worth 1 cent.

but if you aren't going to brew the coffee properly then dont even bother, just stick to whatever swill you are drinking now and live in blissful ignorance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813807
you are correct
tasting notes (for the most part) are 100% total bullshit.
and mostly just bait noobs.
but the list of information i made is useful at the high end of coffee hobbyists.
like sure its from ethiopia but where specifically
ok its from this region but what town
ok its from this town but what farm
usually this is where most people stop but at the absolute top(hundreds of dollars per bag) knowing the exact plots on the farm that the farmers only grow x specific variety can be important.

back on topic
some beans can taste like the tasting notes.
such as medium-medium dark natural process.
nuts, raisins, mulled wine, dried fruit peels are pretty common and distinct flavors for something like burundi natural process.
some high level light roast ethiopians can taste like floral teas.
all assuming you grind and brew correctly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18815553
Depends on what you're trying to use. Direct heat like in a skillet is very difficult to keep from scorching the surface of your beans. Fluid bed roasters like popcorn poppers and Freshroasts are significantly easier, but have trouble maintaining heat if you're going for darker roasts. Drums are a better option for that. People have been "dogbowl" roasting for years.Cheap heat gun pointed at a stainless steel dog bowl and some external way to agitate the beans, but the more control you have the better off you'll be.
https://makezine.com/projects/dog-bowl-coffee-roaster/

>>18811946
Bro just follow the nestle chocolate chip recipe. It's so easy and the cookies taste good every time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18811946
8oz flour
8oz butter
4oz white sugar
4oz brown sugar
1 large egg
1tsp baking powder
1/4tsp salt
dash vanilla
1 cup chocolate chips

Let butter and eggs come to room temperature.
Preheat oven to 350F.
Cream butter and sugar together in mixing bowl.
Add vanilla and egg, mix until homogenous.
In a separate bowl, sift baking powder into flour, add salt, mix thoroughly.
Add chocolate chips to flour, then mix.
Pour flour and chocolate mixture into the bowl of wet ingredients, and mix until homogenous. Avoid overmixing.
Use a tablespoon to portion cookies out onto a parchment lined tray, giving them plenty of space so they dont expand into each other.
Bake for ~10 minutes, let cool until they solidify.

>>18813702
>having to pay your interns
This is baffling to me. The economics are just very strange. For example, many young people looking to further their academic careers but failed to get into a paid PhD program would be willing, if able, to do research unpaid, or even pay for another year of education in the interim before applying again. And yet those hyper-competitive PhD programs still pay salaries (in some form) to their students. However, less-competitive programs do not seem to try to compete with other programs for better students by offering higher salaries, as would be expected in a competitive marketplace, even if they receive a windfall of funding. Part of it's a very intense social psychology for sure -- money is not really supposed to be a motivator -- but at the same time you obviously don't want to shut out, or force extra work upon, those who can't simply live on a parental stipend.

This world of top-tier restaurant internships, and many other classy internships, in theory seems like it should work with at least a somewhat similar mindset -- at least at a certain point the interns should be intrinsically qualified and valuable enough to be paid and competed over, else why have interns in the first place?

It kind of reminds me of that famous 19th-century economist's prediction that the most menial worker's wages would always fall to the bare minimum needed to sustain life. Obviously it's not true in an actual labor market, but doesn't it seem to be even worse in the internship market?

The only thing that made me consider not watching him (besides going back and watching his first two episodes) was that episode which was entirely a paid promotion for a new Disney movie, from beginning to end, including the "history" (completely unrelated to the cuisine, only related to the plot of the film). In fairness he did say at the beginning that Disney asked him to do an episode about this and he agreed because he enjoyed working there, but that's very different from saying at the beginning, "This is a paid promotion." Tbf he's far from the only person to do this. (Freakonomics Radio did a paid (secondary) episode about how much the coauthor liked his Cadillac, also without any clear warning anywhere that it was a paid promotion, for example. Even if you genuinely like the company and product, even if you liked it before you started broadcasting, your TOS for the platform almost always say you have to explicitly announce a paid promotion).

Even in the olden days of TV advertising when TV hosts would themselves make the pitches, it was usually (not always) clear when there was a break from programming to advertising. But as annoying as ad jingles and subliminal messages and the like are, at least modern TV promo ads are almost completely segregated from the content (with important exceptions, which is why I'm using the word 'promo' operatively). I think a reckoning will come when streaming content will have to make this change as well.

There was a decent yt series that only ran a couple episodes, can't remember the name, but the gimmick was that they had three spinners off random ingredients and the chef would have to come up with a meal showcasing whatever three the spinner landed on. The main feature was during the (edited) cooking there were two voice-only commentators giving "live" sports-talk-like commentary, and they actually were really talented (way more so than the chef) -- in addition to having good comedy they had good natural chemistry. So despite the chef being the same in the first episodes and being pretty mediocre, the production quality was good, and of course the commentary was solid, so I actually really liked it. I imagine though, since the commentary track would have to be scripted, that it was a shitload of work to produce and if it wasn't an early hit the comedians probably would have just moved to other projects.

The final cute gimmick they had was their closing scene was the chef saying goodbye while at the sink scrubbing all the pots and pans he used.

He always says he's an amateur and is learning by doing (which often is needed for old recipes anyway) and taking advice from his redditers -- significantly, he's taking and citing that he's receiving help from people on history, language, and cooking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813869
>All of his historical knowledge sounds like it's listed straight off wikipedia.
It's not. (Especially not the Mesoamerican history, since the Wikipedia coverage on that is absolute shit.) Cooking history in general is pretty poorly covered on Wikipedia, with not much rigor -- he'd have to, and clearly does, cross-check every citation and every uncited assertion -- I only wish he'd also edit the page as he did so, but then people would later legit accuse him of doing exactly as you claim (even though the article edit histories could be audited I suppose -- he'd be doing all the video research weeks or months in advance though, so it'd be hard to do in some cases).

Additionally, he also is able to enlist (or even pay?) reddit fans to translate old sources for him. I edit WP history and sometimes I'd really love for a superpower like this -- just being able to call upon a loyal reddit army to reliably translate Medieval X into correct context would be sweet.

>>18815405
They're two different herbal liqueurs. It's much harder to judge liqueurs objectively than it would be to judge, say, brandies or Tequilas, which have pretty tightly defined standards and can be said to outdo each other by how close they are to those standards. Herbal liqueurs are almost universally either old-timey folk medicines that people liked the taste of, or passion projects by people who wanted a liqueur that tasted like the one they made.

To answer your question, Jagermeister has developed and courted a reputation as a party spirit in the United States, so it markets itself on that, whereas Fernet Branca is marketed to Americans as an exotic and cultured drink and therefore pursues nouveau-riche prestige whenever possible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First impression tea notes:
2020 Jinggu (200g)
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/936595693/2020-jinggu-200g

Parameters:
12.2g/100ml water @ 212F gongfu style with short steeps

Taste:
Green bean, a bit green teaish in character (despite having some reddish tinged leaves suggesting some oxidation).
Some of the more traditionally shengy tart apricot and pear flavors.
Moderate bitterness and astringency (I have not had green tea for awhile but again this tea feels like it has a bit of green tea character to it in the way it goes down).
Relatively straightforward but pleasant and easy to drink.

Conclusion:
Seems like a fairly priced daily drinker young sheng, especially if you like a bit of green tea character. Probably a decent cake for newcomers to young sheng as well. At 200g/$20 I don't have any substantial complaints. Though if you dislike green bean taste you may want to stay away.

The internet says it's a yellow tea, I would first try a similar yellow tea. Otherwise, yellow tea is closest to green tea, puerh is probably a poor fit.
https://yunnansourcing.com/products/certified-organic-yunnan-yellow-tea
Note that I haven't specifically tried this, I would prefer one bud one leaf to bud only in this case, and it's cheaper as well. Most people don't really drink yellow tea, I'd order this, potentially this and the bud only tea, and see where you're at. As a bonus, I'd probably throw in some chinese green tea as well.
Mandala tea also aparantly sells some, I also haven't (and probably wouldn't) tried this.

I have actually had that tea a few years back. It is effectively a more lightly oxidized black tea. I recall it having kind of a nice orange marmalade and almond biscotti flavor but also that it could get quite bitter if over brewed (like a lot of black tea).

>>18811219
>I would prefer one bud one leaf to bud only in this case, and it's cheaper as well.
Besides price why? I did not have the pure bud version but I suspect it may be slightly better because the buds will highlight some of that teas lighter more floral elements better over the bitter "maltiness". I do do doubt it is twice as good though so it is not going to be as good of value.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
matcha ice cream:
2qt half & half
12 egg yolks
2 cup sugar or 1 cup erythritol 1 cup allulose (or xylitol) or 2 cup erythritol if eating within 48 hours
matcha (doesn't matter, the sugar and cream is gonna murder any subtleties of the leaf)
25 dollar walmart churn https://www.walmart.com/ip/Nostalgia-4-Quart-Electric-Ice-Cream-Maker-Blue/749542584
big boxes of salt

1. make matcha with the half & half. it honestly doesn't matter how much you make, i've used just fuck my shit up levels and it was perfectly fine. it just has to dissolve
2. put a metal bowl on the stove and dump everything in it. remember to break yolks. add pinch of salt. turn the heat to maximum and stir it
3. you can do this until either the sugar is fully dissolved or to official guideline which is like 150F to kill salmonella. use infrared thermometer and remember what temperature you turned the heat off at for next time
4. dump ice cream custard into ice cream maker cylinder and put it in the fridge for a few hours
5. make lots of ice sitting in the freezer the day before
6. put cylinder in bucket, put paddle in cylinder, put motor on, dump layer of ice, layer of salt till it's full and plug in
7. churn for about 20-30 min or until it fails to churn. if you used sugar or plain erythritol, it's ready to eat. if you used erythritol with alluose (or xylitol), it needs a day or two in the freezer to get firmer. the bottom is usually ready though.

>>18817346
You can put this to a test actually! Get a timer or stopwatch, a measuring cup and turn on your faucet for 15 seconds. Multiply the amount of water you've collected and you have your faucets output by mintute. Your dishwasher has a user manual that will tell you how many gallons or liters it uses per cycle, but if you don't trust this you can monitor your water meter and see for yourself! If it was manufactured after 2010, it likely uses somewhere between 2 and 4 gallons per cycle.

Now that you've established how much water you use per minute from your faucet, time yourself washing your dishes. With some simple math, you'll see if your feeling about water and energy use is correct or not (it won't be, by the way).

I can walk for 6 minutes with my girlfriend, or 4 minutes by myself, and reach 3 grocery stores, a liquor store, gas stations, multiple coffee shops, multiple fast food, an italian restaurant, vietnamese, thai buffet, 2 indian restaurants, sushi bar, boba tea shop, multiple gyms, multiple all-night bodegas, a head shop, a hookah bar, multiple strip clubs, multiple churches, a public pool, a park, a dogpark, bicycle trail, jogging path, a mosque, a temple, wherever Sikhs go to worship, Metro bus routes, a cell phone store, and Shipleys (a donut shop). The furthest thing from us is the boba tea shop, which is 8 minutes walking with her.

Used to take us 10 minutes together but I made her develop some stamina and take the stairs instead of elevator.
Houston is also known for having some of the worst public transportation in the US.
So, instead of blaming the city for public transportation or homeless encampments or for a lack of walkability, blame them and the state for zoning laws. Zoning laws are the least free thing ever. Telling people what they can or can't do with their own property based on arbitrary lines drawn on a map by politicians? Kek.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813328
Take a basic lean bread recipe. 5/3 flour to water. For 20oz of flour, use 2tsp salt, 1/2tsp yeast, and 1oz olive oil(don't buy it at the grocery store, grocery store oil is adulterated and rancid, regardless of what the bottle says).

Literally just mix this all together into a dough ball, then need it until the dough is smooth and you can stretch part of it thin enough light passes through.

Then portion it into however many pizzas you are making, and ball it.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oZxNbL5XB7w

Then shove each dough ball in an oiled, sealed container that's big enough to allow it to expand, then shove those containers in the fridge for 48 hours.

Come back, let them warm up enough to work with, and then stretch them out. The dough should be quite thin, 1/3 an inch, with a bit more on the edges.

kneading high hydration dough by hand is a waste of time. it will form a strong gluten network by itself over a period of several hours (google autolysis). all you had to do was wait - you could have simply tossed it in the refrigerator overnight - but your impatience and inexperience got the best of you. I made some ciabatta this weekend that was 100% hydration - 400g of flour, 400g of water, and it tightened up nicely and was trivial to work with after simply resting a few hours.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813932
5 minutes by hand is approximately nothing. I knead my pasta dough for around 10 minutes and pasta dough builds gluten very quickly. for a pizza dough you're looking at 30-60 minutes of hand kneading depending on exactly how wet your dough is, what type of flour you are using, and what additions you're using.
>>18813940
yeah he used a mixer with a dough hook. if you don't have a machine to do the kneading then you're better off just letting the gluten build up naturally through autolysis. wet dough responds very slowly to kneading, you could easily spend an hour by hand to get the level of gluten development he got in just a few minutes on the machine, or you could just give it a few folds every hour for a few hours and get the same result with a lot less work.

Experts (who also have made pizza in home ovens) have advised to use a high hydration dough to compensate for the longer cooking time that dough requires when cooking in a home ovens compared to the much higher heat of restaurant pizza ovens.

So use a hydration of no less than 68%. 70% hydration probably is best, and any higher than that and you'll have a bad time actually trying to work and shape your dough and all that.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18814073
Why would you want it to rise before putting it in the freezer like it's the oven? There's absolutely no point to that. It's better to freeze an unrisen dough. Not only does it take up less room in the freezer but any air bubbles will collapse in the freezer anyway due to negative thermal expansion. When you freeze anything you should have it sealed in an airtight bag and press out any air that you can.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've had good luck with my pizza's recently. I use this recipe...

3 cups of flour (2 white 1 wheat or all white)
3 tsp yeast (standard red star stuff you can get in most grocery stores.
Optional: a tbsp or two of sugar
1-2 cups of HOT HOT, but not boiling, water

First: You'll need a baking stone in the oven.

Methodology, flour and yeast in bowl, mix / fluff (you could also just sift). Add one cup of water mix throughout with your hand until fully absorbed. Start adding small amounts of water and repeat the mixing until you get large clumps that are not sticky to the touch. Knead until all flour in incorporated and the dough is slightly sticky. Leave it alone for 20 minutes. Come back and turn dough into ball (the one you see all the pro chefs do on youtube). Then cover in a dusting of flour and bag the bowl or put a lid on it.

Now you wait at least one hour, but preferably an afternoon or so before rolling it out and putting toppings on it.

To cook it; turn the oven on 30-60 minutes before the pizza goes in and turn it on high. Like 500 F. Top pizza, put in for 5 minutes, turn and check on cheese / crust, cook for another 4-5 minutes and take out.

>>18813328
>teach me how to make a good pizza dough
For an 18" crust :
1 US cup of water
Yeast (1 tbsp or so)
Olive oil (1/4 cup or less)
Salt (1 tbsp or less)
Flour

Mix all this together. You'll need enough flour to get the dough just sticky, but not to much. The other measurements are up to taste, really. I always eyeball it.
Kneed - you should have learned this from your mother. Or at school. Watch a YT if you dunno how.
Cover with olive oil, let it rest. A long slow rest at low temp (cook room for 6 hours) will give you a better dough the a short fast rest a higher temp.

Then you will grease your pan and spread out the dough. Or flour a counter top and roll out your dough.

If you want to get fancy, make a pre-ferment : 1 cup flour, 1 cup water, yeast. You mix all this up the night before and let the yeast have fun over night. Add in the oil, salt and rest of the flour the next morning and let it rise all day.

A wetter (aka stickier) dough will make a better crust but will be harder to kneed if you are doing it by hand.

Four Loko is illegal because it contains both alcohol and caffeine, which when combined can lead to a state of wide-awake drunk, where a person may feel alert and able to drive or make other poor decisions while still under the influence of alcohol. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) banned Four Loko in 2010, citing safety concerns associated with the combination of caffeine and alcohol.

On the other hand, Irish coffee is legal because it contains only alcohol and caffeine from coffee, and not in a combination that would create a dangerous state. The amount of caffeine in Irish coffee is generally lower than the amount found in energy drinks and it is not mixed with other stimulants.
Additionally, Irish coffee is typically consumed in a more controlled setting, such as a bar or restaurant, where a person is less likely to engage in risky behavior, while energy drinks like Four Loko are often consumed in a party or social setting where excessive drinking is more likely to occur.

>>18801313
There are a couple inaccuracies here but that image is 95% correct. Jesus probably didn't believe he himself was the messiah. He believed the messiah was about to show up and he called this messiah the "son of man." Jesus was basically a doomsday nut, which there were a lot of in the holy land at that time because of mounting tensions between Jews and the Romans - this led to a lot of doomsday nuts who believed that God was about to overthrow the Romans and establish His Good Kingdom on earth, but they (the Jews) just had to wait a little longer (and suffer under the Romans). It also leaves out a couple important details like why Jesus was crucified (the answer is that someone, possibly Judas, told the Romans that Jesus was claiming behind closed doors to be the king of the Kingdom of Heaven, and the romans interpreted this as insurrectionist speech).

Okay I don't dispute the paedophilia of historical eras (even our current era desu) but the "27 on average" thing is honestly bullshit-- it's a result of how statistics work. Typically people didn't make it past age 5 as a result of infant mortality and disease, which meant that the average living age, when mapped out, was lower.

But on actual averages, people have lived into their sixties since the dawn of time. "Natural" deaths under 50 that weren't a result of disease were always considered shocking and there has never been an era of human history where dying under 30 was considered expected unless the deceased was already ill.

>>18813813
It depends on the type of rice down to the specific cultivar really, but great rice is when you coax the most flavor and desirable texture out of your rice.

If you cook rice exactly the same every time you are not good at cooking rice. As rice ages, and the variance from bag to bag it needs adjustment in the cooking process, mainly more or less water.

Rice cookers are convenient because they hold the rice at a warm temperature after they are done and you literally can't fuck it up unless you mismeasure. It's one task that no longer requires your attention at all(whereas stovetop rice requires you to at least be minimally aware and can be burnt). Many people are very anxious in the kitchen, so they overvalue the idiot-proof nature of the rice cooker.

That being said, if you eat rice every day they are great. A good rice cooker can not only cook perfect rice without effort, it can also hot hold it all day, and reheat leftover rice perfectly.

Personally, I mostly eat Basmati rice at home, so I just boil it like pasta if I want plain rice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813853
>>18814657
No, the previous anon is 100% correct. I cook over 90 litres of sushi rice a week and the amount of water required to get the correct consistency varies from an even 1/1 ratio to 1/1.25 depending on the crop. As we get later in the season it gets drier and drier. Me and the sushi chef taste every single batch. It needs to have a specific firmness, and the release of starch also needs to be controlled so it's slightly sticky, meaning that I also vary the amount of rice conditioner and the time I spend rinsing it. The quality of the rice also varies along what proportion of the rice grains are broken; with higher proportions from lower quality crops(like the most recent Calrose crop) requiring additional rinsing as the broken grains release more starch,

I used to be quite fat. The potato diet as mentioned is solid, but it's not reliant on potatoes at all. Ray Cronise, who originated it only picked potatoes because he knew Penn Jillette liked them. But anything simple, like rice and beans or virtually anything bland will suffice. The goal is to reset taste buds so you're not eating for pleasure, you are eating for survival. It doesn't really matter because it's not meant to be a long term diet. The point is to change your relationship to the food you eat.

That said, I went with what to this day I call the Stalone method. I reme as a fat kid watching some old talk show where they asked him how he was always in such good shape.

He said its easy, if you eat well and exercise 5 days a week, when it comes to the weekend you can do whatever. "Pizza, hamburgers, ice cream... doesn't matter. You've done good it's covered" pretty similar to how the rock now talks about cheat days. It really works though.

And here's a thing, I used to drink Coke like crazy, but on that cut it out other than weekends. The first week was awful and coke on Saturday felt like an amazing relief. The second week it was tasty but I didn't crave it like I one did. The third week I drank it mostly just cause I could. By week 4 I did bother, it seemed gross.

Now I have it on rare occasion and it's an intense treat but that's it.

You have to work with your will power and habits first, anon. No diet trick is going to help because you're trying to build a house by starting from the roof instead of the ground.
I'm not going to send you to the gym or jogg, because this starts with the mind. Set yourself some goals you can achieve. Make your bed everyday when you wake up, even if its annoying. Wash your dishes immediately after eating. Clean that room/garage/backyard that you have been postponing for ages. Sell that extra thing you keep saving in your closet/attic/basement.
Try to get involved with community work, find a new hobbie, try to meet people in events and such.
Good habits work like chain, once you get one the next will follow. If you look forward to do something then you'll want to be at your best, to show your friends and people you care about that you're still made of good stuff, just like them.
Once you finish what you start, and once you get the will to do things that you don't want to do, but you still accomplish them, then you'll have the solid ground to face this with bigger weapons.

Still, it's not only about what you cook. You must understand your metabolism. You are obviously insulin resistant, and yout gut microbiome is also fucked up.
You have to eat more protein and fiber, foods that will saciate you. You say that you always want another dish right? It's not the same to eat a second plate of steak than a second plate of spaghetti. Eat things thats require a lot of chewing, get your jaw exhausted so your hunger becomes something secondary. There is tricks to fill your belly too. Drink a big glass of water before meals. Have some collagen peptide supplements to entertain your stomach with it before meals, it has zero calories and it's healthy. You don't need to starve yourself at the start, you can eat as always and then choose a time (6 pm) to stop eating until next morning. Half fasts are good for this, it will help you control your cravings.

mix cooked white rice with a little coconut oil (just for texture, not for flavor) with some light spices like some dried garlic and pepper. Have that as your baseline filler food because it's pretty easy to add things to it to make you not hate it, like a little cream or some mushrooms.

But if you really need to lose weight, do what i've been doing: pick a day, and do one situp, one pushup, and one pullup. Then, the next day, do one more. Don't ever take a day off. It's only ever one more than the day before, so it's never too much to ask, and eventually it becomes a habit that you don't want to break. You'll get to the point of where your regular muscle you normally have will finally be tested (for me it was around ten days) and you'll want to stop, but it'll be a hundred times easier to keep going because instead of jumping right in to a large number, you had a slow, methodical increase which means your cardio will never be too overtaxed.
Remember: the key to change that sticks is not dramatic changes, it's small, easily-maintainable alterations that can synergize. Don't fad diet and only fad diet, do a little diet, a little exercise, and a little habit alteration, then when those become normal, do a little more.

Don’t drink your calories. Soda and fruit juice will not satisfy your need for food and provide little nutritional benefit. Be wary about how much oil you use, even 1 tablespoon of olive oil has a lot of calories. Salad dressings and some sandwich spreads are also a common trap when it comes to this, adding too much sugar or cream to coffee can be this too.

Replace unhealthy food you eat with a healthier alternative. If you have a sweet tooth, eat fruit instead of chocolate. If you like to snack, think of a healthier snack to munch on. Fruits and vegetables are good for this because they’re light on calories. Unsalted nuts are decent too so long as you pay attention to portion sizes. Honey may seem “healthier” but it really isn’t that much better. Consider baking food you may normally fry since you won’t need to use as much oil. Breakfasts are some of the least healthy foods people often eat, many of them are like desserts

Eat food with a lot of fiber, because that will fill you up more. Fruits, vegetables, whole grains are all good for this.

Drink plenty of water

Minimize eating out, be very careful about prepackaged meals. When you eat food prepared by someone else you have no control over the ingredients being used. A lot of food in restaurants or prepackaged foods are designed by a profit-seeking business to be tasty to increase demand, not necessarily to be healthy

Eat slowly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you're 450 lb you can lose a lot of weight without trying too hard with your diet.

The most important thing is the quantity of what you eat. The first step is to train the stomach to accept less food and shrink to a smaller size. What worked for me in the past is to do 16 hour fasts and only eat within an 8 hour window in the day. So only eat at lunch, then dinner at 6, maybe a snack at 7:45 if you want. And since you're 470lb, you can eat big portions and still lose weight. You still have to give up binging on fast food if you're doing that, your meal will have to be actually healthy foods.

The simplest go-to is protein (chicken, pork, beef that you've cooked) and vegetables (broccoli, asparagus, etc). But you can eat as big a portion as you want since you're 470lb, you'll lose a ton of weight within a couple of months. For snacks just eat more protein, maybe cured meats like salami and jerkey, cheese. Just don't eat potato chips or anything sweet. A 470lber needs to cut out starches and sugars to start building back insulin function, and it will keep you less hungry. No need to go full keto though, like you can have something like mashed potato within reason (not every day).

If you follow this for just a few days, you'll find that it becomes easy after maybe 4-5 days as your stomach shrinks. Only the first 2-3 days are hard, it's literally effortless from there.
This is a cheat/cope type of weight loss, but it's a very good place to start. After you gain momentum, you can try looking more seriously into your diet and look into exercising.

You can't be morbidly obese on a proper diet. It's not a matter of eating less, but rather of eating better (healthier).
To put it simply, you need to cut sugar, salt and processed foods from your diet. Ideally cut on fats too, not because non-trans fats are inherently unhealthy (like refined sugars are) but because they are calorie dense.
If you accept and stick to a veggie and lean meat based diet you can have 3 helpings and you will still lose weight. Also drink water and tea.

We can't give you self-control, you are ultimately responsible for helping yourself. You need to find a routine you can sustain, and cooking whole meals (no processed bullshit) is fairly quick and easy. For starters:

- drink only water, carbonated water (no sweetner) and black coffee, absolutely no exceptions.

- have a dedicated window to eat each day. I find one meal a day easier to manage if you got a routine like going to work, and just drink coffee and water to suppress your appetite in between.

- meat do salmon, tuna, and chicken preferably baked in the oven. You can throw fresh vegies in the pan too (broccoli, cauliflower, etc.). Frozen is fine, avoid potatoes, rice, and most other starchy vegetables. If you do eat potatoes, sweet potato bake not fry.

- count your calories for the first week or so, so you get an idea of what your portion sizes should look like.

Alright. Said I would do this last night but I had no time. Let's do a quick version and if you're interesting further I can put more detail into it.

Disclaimer: Like the other anons said, you're going to need a little bit of self-control and motivation as well. You probably have that already. Don't worry, some of the posts telling you that you'll be hungry all the time are retarded. You won't. Though I am not 100% certain the 1st week or few days MAY have you feeling hungry regardless, after a couple weeks you'll fall into a rhythm and it will be smooth.

:::Part 1 (Macros):

1g fat = 9 calories
1g protein = 4 calories
1g carbs = 4 calories

Remember that. Food nutrition is split up between macro nutrients (fat/protein/carbs) that give you your energy and building blocks, and micro nutrients (vitamins/minerals) which supply your body with a host of important matter it will *need* to function correctly, if not optimally.

:::Part 2 (Micros):

Please look into getting an account on Cronometer. Just google it. It's free and you don't need the membership. You can use it to track your total calories intake and your vitamin and mineral intake, but it's mostly there for now so you can see which foods will supply you with what. This is for the long-term picture so you get to understand what's good and what isn't and, hopefully one day, learn to cook for yourself beyond the absolute basics.

Additionally, I highly recommend you look into getting a quality multi-vitamin. It will make the process easier and potentially fix some other problems you may have. If you're in the US or Canada you should try and find Vitamin Code for Men supplements, they are raw ingredients only and of the highest quality. Pic related is what I use. Being realistic here, you are not going to hit 100% of nutritional targets so it's important you use this. Mine didn't come with probiotics & enzymes but don't worry about that if yours also doesn't, I'll supply you with some recs.

Okay, moving on.

:::Part 3 (Kitchen tools):

Watch this vid and acquire most of the tools there:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H31YI223zG4&list=PL9_z7arfoMrsZM7J2D80YYvSzZXJ9lVbe&index=3

You don't *need* an air fryer but the others I'd recommend heavily. A good pots & pans set that will set you up for being healthy and is non-stick is by the name Greenpan. I use them personally and it is the healthiest non-stick set you can get. PFOA, PFAS, PTFE free.

:::Part 4 (Intermittent Fasting):

Beginner guide:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jqZsS03dlPk

When you see the word "fasting", it's not really fasting. It's time-restricted eating, which is a lot healthier and more natural than gorging yourself on food every 2-3 hours. You have an eating window you eat food in, and the the rest of the time you only drink water or things that do not contain any macros (fat/protein/carbs), like tea. I've gotten to the point where I legitimately never feel hungry outside the eating window or even think about food (unless I'm looking up a recipe intentionally) and I'm barely hungry even when it's time to eat, but I still enjoy the food of course.

I recommend starting out with 16:8, meaning you do not eat for 16 hours and eat for 8. 10 AM to 6 PM is generally the accepted starting point. You break your fast with your first bite of breakfast at 10 AM and take your last bite of dinner by 6PM at the latest.

:::Part 5 (The rough diet):

You said you're 470 lbs. That's a lot. I'll set you up with a 2200 calorie diet for now (you can reduce by 100 calories every 70-80 pounds or so or just plateau at 2000 and you'll be fine. So, a 2200 calorie diet. What does this mean macro-wise?

80g of fat (720 calories)
200g of protein (800 calories)
170g of carbs (640 calories)

Listen, if this sounds autistic, don't worry. You don't need to hit these exacts targets. Just try and hover close to them. Within 10g of each (5g of fat) and you are good. I gave you a conservative estimate of your protein intake relative to your weight.

If you still feel hungry, you can up the protein by 20g or so at a time and see if you're still hungry. For protein, the way to calculate the minimum you should be eating is 0.8g of protein per kg of bodyweight. You can easily go up to 1g+ and still feel fine. Bodybuilders for example go pas that point, but unless you're determined to exercise hard, I would not recommend it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
heres a recipe I made for a friend for my lasagna.

I never used a written recipe and learned from watching someone else make it. They never used a written recipe either.

all amounts were pulled out of my ass based on a best guess for the recipe. because the amounts of many of the seasonings don't matter that much. The person I gave it to said it was the best lasagna they had ever had. they had no trouble making it and never questioned me on exact measurements.

2 lbs. sweet and/or hot Italian sausage
1 package Lasagna Noodles
1 Table spoon olive oil
2 16oz. cans diced or crushed stewed tomatoes
2 or 3 lbs. Mozzarella cheese
Italian seasoning
dried chopped parsley
2 or 3 pints ricotta cheese
2 or 3 eggs
1 white onion medium to large
6 to 8 medium size mushrooms
2 or 3 cloves fresh garlic

Mix the 2 or 3 eggs, 2 or 3 tablespoons parsley, and Ricotta cheese together.

Chop the Mushrooms.

Boil the noodles in a large saucepan with the oil, and 1 tsp. salt in the water,
cook until still tough. drain and refill pan with cold water to keep noodles from
sticking together.

Coarse chop the onion, smash and finely dice 1 or 2 cloves of garlic.
Remove the sausage casing, and break up the sausage in a frying pan.
Brown the sausage with 2/3 the onion and all the garlic, salt and pepper to taste.
Drain off the grease.

In a 2 quart sauce pan combine the Stewed tomatoes, 1 tsp. Italian seasoning, the rest of the onion, 1 crushed and finely chopped clove of garlic, the mushrooms, and the Sausage.
bring to boil and then simmer about 15 minutes.

Arrange in layers in a ungreased 9x13" pan: sauce, ricotta cheese, mozzarella, and pasta.
Top the last layer with a generous amount of mozzarella.
Bake at 350 for 20 to 25 minutes or until sauce bubbles and the cheese is slightly brown.

Well it depends on what you call demi-glace in the first place. The industry standard for demiglace today is basically a highly reduced stock and contains no sauce espagnole or starch thickening.

As for what I personally like to do when I make demiglace, I don't just use bones. I use mostly meat and *some* bones. I don't know why so many cooks today say bones have more flavor than meat; it's simply not true.

My theory on why these youtube chefs say to use mostly or all bones is because they can only think in terms of restaurant production, and in restaurants pretty much all the meat you have goes into making the actual food like steaks, soups, stews, roasts, etc. So what they have left over are just the bones so that's all they use for stock.
This is why Escoffier's methods and teachings suck for today's culinary world and especially sucks for home cooks. His methods are guides for the restaurants. Escoffier is meant as a reference for a professional kitchen and is of limited use to the amateur home cook. Youtube cooks who worked in restaurant kitchens suck at teaching home cooks for this same reason. And this is besides the fact that many of Escoffier's teachings are outdated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18811151
More meat is better for /my/ taste because there’s more actual meat flavor in meat while bones are good for lending gelatin to the stock.

What’s outdated about Escoffier is the use of sauce espagnole since nobody actually makes that sauce anymore, his recipes for demiglace and bechamel in that the demiglace uses roux and sauce espagnole and how his bechamel uses veal stock, but the most outdated thing about Escoffier to me is his heavy emphasis on sauces in general.

Wolfgang Puck spoke on the historical context for this:
In Escoffier’s day the food wasn’t that great. Restaurants weren’t as efficient because they didn’t have the modern technology, logistics, and infrastructure we have today, ingredients weren’t the freshest, and food preservation methods were lacking and poorly understood compared to today.
So sauces were highly emphasized as a way to cover things up. Lacking or even off-putting flavors got covered up by sauce. Even mistakes like overcooked or burned food would be hidden by a sauce slathered all over on top of the food.
This is why fancy restaurants today mostly tend to put sauce on the plate, below the food, with the food like the steak or whatever sitting on top of the sauce. Because today’s kitchens don’t have to worry about covering up their mistakes so much while back in Escoffier’s day covering up mistakes or making up for lacking food was the mindset of the restaurant kitchen industry.
According to Wolfgang Puck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ricotta is made from leftover whey from cheesemaking. To make the cheese you add rennet to milk, which curdles it into curds and whey (sweet whey). You make the first cheese from the curds. Then you curdle the whey again, this time by using acid. The acid gets the remaining proteins to curdle that the rennet couldn't. Then you strain the ricotta curds from the whey (now acid whey). You get a very low yield of very fine curds.

It's still made from curds, so it's still cheese.

You want at least double the vinegar as your peppers...you can also add water in place of vinegar to change/dilute the flavor a bit.

Hard to duck up honestly but getting it perfected can take years...it's a lot to your liking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Something to be aware of... Your gut biome is what it is based on the past few months of your diet.

If your diet has been 100% cheeseburgers for 6 months, the bacteria most suited for breaking down cheeseburgers is going to be dominant in your gut. The bacteria best suited for breaking down an all-raw-veg diet might be living life as a serious minority. If you suddenly change your intake, your body won't be very well equipped to break it down and digest it - resulting in gas/bloating/indigestion and just feeling a bit shitty... It takes your gut a bit of time to adjust, so you can either push through it and know that it'll improve, or do a slower more phased improvement.

I've witnessed too many people transform their diet overnight, feel worse and return to bad foods entirely. All because their gut wasn't prepared for digesting mass quantities of healthier foods. The guts population and demographic ratios can adjust within a week or two though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18816988
>What is your favorite cooking wine?

whatever is left over. I keep leftover wine in my refrigerator, with a vacuum stopper applied. I also keep vermouth in the fridge. if I need white or red wine, I first look for a leftover bottle, and if I don't find one, then I just use vermouth. Very simple.

>What do you use it for?
Pan sauces, braises, and the like. it usually for deglazing, but sometimes I need to add a cup or so to make a reduction or to flavor a sauce

>Do you drink it too
It depends. If I opened a bottle to have with the food, then yes, I will drink and cook with it. If I'm using what was leftover in the refrigerator, then no, I won't drink it if it's more than a day old.

posts.com: You know, I expected way less from this country's cuisine, but it's actually really nice. It's kinda like Thai cuisine that allows you to actually taste what you're eating rather than drown it in a small village's worth of chili pepper (I know there's a lot of Thai dishes that don't overload on the pungency fuck off it's a metaphor)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I was kind of surprised by how good Khmer food was. The problem is that it's virtually impossible to get outside of Cambodia. It's like, I can get pretty good Thai food where I live, but if you look online at recipes they're always like, "you can sub ginger for galangal, and lime zest for lime leaves, and basil or mint for thai basil, and jalapenos for thai chilis, and if you can't find lemongrass it's okay to leave it out..." and I'm like, no. You really can't substitute any of those things. Fortunately all of those things are really easy to find, but with Cambodian food they have their own versions of all of those things except there is literally zero market for those ingredient abroad unless you live in like the ghetto part of North Providence.

posts.com:
Growing up as an amerigolem, my knowledge of salad was iceberg lettuce, chedder cheese, ranch, and croutons.

I will share with you holy wisdom revealed unto me
>take your boring ass vegetables of choice. Some lettuce/spinach/arugula or whatever
>take a can of sardines smoked in olive oil
>dump the entire thing on top of the salad
>break up the deenz
>add an acid of some sort. The brine from a jar of stuffed garlic, balsamic vinegar, apple cider vinegar
>slice up some garlic stuffed olives and throw them on
>add honey
>add a crunchy but soft nut like walnuts or cashews
>add raisins or some other dried fruit
>freshly ground black pepper
>mix it all together
Wa la.
It actually fills you up and tastes good. Thank you for reading my blog.

Okay so for a 25l wash I am using 6 small tins of Lyle's black strap molasses, 2kg Demerara and 1kg of muscvado.
If I run it through my pot still after foreshots and heads I cut down to about 50ish% and redistill everything after that.
With the reflux it comes out 93-96% first pass... The major difference in taste is coming from oak but that's subjective I guess.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18810815
One of my friends is doing his first rum and chose to do 100% molasses with yeast nutrient. It has been cold so fermentation has been a bit slow even with a heating belt. Should be fun to see how it turns out.
Done some really nice plum brandy that has this sweet and creamy taste to it. The good stuff was from about 60%-45%abv, 30% abv was bad smelling, so it was tossed and then down at 10% some fruity aromas showed up. The blended cuts came out right at 50%. Fun process and a good excuse to drink a little in the afternoon hah.

Okay I had the rums. Here is Jap rum tasting notes.

Smell:
Vanilla, carmelly oak almost bourbon like, but with less char.

Taste:
A little spicy, unique smooth molasses kind of flavor, limited to no funk, possibly some earthy kind of flavors. Sherry like finish.

Very good stuff. Worth the price. Quite complex once diluted down from the 62.1% will look at reviews of the other casks for sale and pic a second and maybe third.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
24 yr Grenada rum bottle 229/336

Vanilla cake, caramel, cedar, old books, nutty, maybe cinnamon as well

Herbal, subtle and refined flavors, minty, well integrated oak, subtle tropical funk, jordan almonds.

Really really nice, complex, refined, delicious. Yeah, probably worth the price. This one was quite challenging to pick apart the flavor and aroma. Pretty much every sip tasted different.

posts.com: Can I make something like Coq Au Vin or else with a thick gravy/sauce in a pressure canner or is it not possible? I want to have this incase I don't want to spend a few hours cooking...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18816203
Yeah, with a proper pressure canner you can preserve almost anything that won't turn to mush during the process. Note: a pressure cooker is not a pressure canner, it doesn't hold the same ptessire and won't maintain a high enough temperature to make food shelf stable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18816203
Yes you can. Just be sure to follow temp/pressure guidelines for meat, have the right amount of head space, and you should be good to go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18816236
you want to make sure it's barely cooked before you pressure can it - you want to get it up to ~200F so it won't thermally stress the hot jars when you load them, then allow the food to cook during the pressure canning process.

sometimes children hold their poop if they feel like they have no other control over their lives. maybe shes miserable and is just acting out. Its hard to say with just random information on a mongolian basket weaving forum tho.


If nothing works then your whole family needs to change their diet and you need to strictly control what she has access to. Basically give her no choice and drag the entire family along to eat the stuff she wont eat but needs to. Its kinda like dieting: its easier to do if you have other people to suffer through it with you. Dont give her snacks or let her hang out with other people who might feed her. After about 2-3 weeks of eating what she hates, her body will adapt and start to like it. Its easy to say 'oh no she will starve to death' but the human body literally has a biological function to prevent that, which are your taste buds. The taste buds acclimate to whatever is chronically consumed. Understand that and force a habit change.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18814133
Even if you raise a milking cow as a companion animal, like a dog or cat, the only way to get cattle to give milk is through insemination so in most situations, you can't separate the veal industry from the dairy industry. Cattle don't give milk unless they've calfed and calves, if male, go on to become beef or veal. Not to mention that if you've kept a cow as a companion animal and inseminated it so she'd give milk, taking the calf away from its mother so you can enjoy the milk is viewed as an act of violence and exploitation.
In India, male calves become draft animals, which veganism is also opposed to as another example of animal exploitation.

The only thing vegans can't argue against based on these points is eggs. Chickens lay eggs regardless of what you do. Most chickens will not go broody (IE develop a nesting instinct towards the eggs she shits out) and not utilising the eggs would be a waste. The argument goes that eating such eggs is /symbolic of exploitation and violence towards animals/. There are people literally starving for eggs and these self-righteous fucks are worried about symbolism.

So yeah, I don't see eggs from companion hens are verboten in a vegan diet but absolutely understand the point against dairy.
That said, I just had a sausage, egg and cheese croissant this morning so lol.

You misunderstand the point of veganism. Of course, ideally, a vegan would want to cause zero harm to the world but as that is nothing more than fantasy, the aim of ethical veganism is to cause /as little harm as possible/. To reduce harm to cattle, giving up meat and dairy is possible while reducing harm to field voles and silo mice is impossible due to the need for vegans to eat produce, legumes and grains, the harvesting of which will invariably lead to harm to these and other animals.
Most ethical vegans who aren't complete idiots understand that and understand that their diets and lifestyles are the result of first world privilege, that people in Greenland or Ulanfuckingbatar don't always have the luxury to choose vegetables over meat, eggs or dairy, that their clothing and iPhones are the direct results of exploitation of living beings, human or otherwise. They get it. But at the very least, they try to limit the harm they do rather than throwing their hands up and declaring all attempts as mere exercises in futility.
I'm not vegan myself and most vegans I've talked to are horrifically stupid, annoying and shortsighted cunts who make diet into a personality, but the few I've encountered who do so in the manner I outlined above have been absolutely lovely people.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18813207
Instead of buying fresh onions, replace your frozen veggie blend with a frozen mirepoix/soup vegetable/whatever it's labeled as. It'll be onion, carrot, celery, and sometimes green pepper. They'll be diced smaller and have a flavour that better suits omelette stuffing. Just saute them in a bit of oil with salt and pepper(hot sauce as well if you like) and when they are soft set them aside.

For a meat filling, it'll be difficult to beat hotdogs for price, but check for marked down ground pork or breakfast sausage. at 50% off they can match or beat the price of hotdogs. Or, if you are truly desperate, downgrade from regular hotdogs to chicken weiners.

For eggs, not much you can do. If you have access to someone who works at a restaurant you can try and buy some through them; especially food service liquid whole egg.

Finally, you are eating hotdog omelettes; go to a foodbank.
